comment: "Pitched idea, wrote story, and completed several rounds of edits on very short (24-48 hour) turnaround opinion piece/essay for PostEverything section. Once story was published, editor never responded to any of my further emails about payment and invoicing. Followed up repeatedly before giving up in anger and frustration, galled by the unprofessionalism. Am stunned if this is standard for the Post. Am even more surprised editors don't realize that writers share this sort of information, and that they don't care if they develop a reputation as a person and publication to avoid."
"Received payment 4 days after publication. Editor easy to work with."

"Have found w WaPo it *really* depends on the editor. Wish Who Pays Writers would let you id editor when submitting info for this reason: Because the editor on this assignment was fantastic. The assignment I did for WaPo right after this one, though, went horribly--of course, it was a different editor. It really and truly depends on who you get: Writer's experience with them can be night and day."
relationship: Ongoing/pre-existing relationship with editor or publication

comment: "Good experience. Essay accepted and published within 48 hours. Payment received in 2 weeks by direct deposit."
"I'm a freelance classical music critic for the Post.  I get paid $125.00 for each concert review (250-300 words).  "

comment: "Months of back and forth and waiting. Ultimately, I probably lost money writing this for the Post at this price. At $1,000, maybe it would have been worth the trouble. I believe many Post editors will ask a few questions about your pitch and then stop responding because they take the pitch and assign it to a staff writer, cutting you out of the picture."
relationship: Ongoing/pre-existing relationship with editor or publication

comment: ""$250 if it runs inside, $500 if it's on the section front""
